Interviewer: Given the reliance on Intel's DPP implementation for performance optimizations, how did you approach the analysis to determine the most effective configurations for the EPYC servers? Additionally, can you discuss any specific metrics or methodologies you used to quantify and compare the performance impact of different configurations, especially in the context of large language models and other HPC workloads? 


Interviewee: So the way we go about, so the way we go about to analyze which configuration is the best, is to do a, sweep on different parameters. For instance, in my large language model, the number of input tokens I give to the model is one such parameter which I can change. Similarly, the maximum output tokens, the model can generate is another parameter. And the number of course on which the model is being deployed at is one such parameter. So the way we go about it is we do a sweep from, the for each parameter and find out which parameter is giving us the best performance for that particular sweep. We also define a default configuration, which generally is the mean of every single configuration, every single parameter we have defined. And then we see that for each week, whether the performance is decreasing or increasing with respect to the default configuration, which I have defined. And once I understand that this particular data point is giving me the maximum performance, I define that to be my default configuration.

Input Text:
Interviewer: Your approach to anomaly detection using ARIMA and a three-sigma threshold is a classic yet effective method, especially given the constraints of data availability and the need to minimize false alarms. For the FDC data, clustering is a powerful technique for identifying patterns and anomalies. Could you elaborate on the specific clustering algorithms you found most effective for FDC data, and how you validated the clusters to ensure they accurately represented normal and anomalous behavior?  

Interviewee: Okay, so that is a very interesting question. And actually that is what made the task the most challenging for us now initially. Well, now the thing is one of the challenges of using the time series data is if you try to like initially I would use the hierarchical clustering method to Cluster based on the time series data, but that would take up too much amount of time. And because the production is a very fast process so it became like necessary that we can do it efficiently and like in a very short period of time so that's why what I did is at first I will use the PCA the principal component analysis method to do the dimensionality reduction on the time series data and bring it down to a 2d space. And now that we have it in the 2D space then I will use the clustering method. So here initially I started with the came in clustering method, but the problem with the came in clustering is it is like a distance Place method. So all the Clusters that will be formed is will always be in a circle. but in this particular case when you project it to the lower Dimension does not always mean that that they should be in the circular form like all the Clusters so it became more important to to take into consideration the the density as well as like the distribution of each of the like points. And so as far as the distribution based clustering is concerned so I use the gaussian mixture model for the clustering and yeah, so and then like what I will do is like for example during the training period I will have the Clusters and then I will note down like which pattern will belong to which clusters like by that I mean that even though the clustering is done on the two-dimensional space, but the pattern will then be Taken for the time series data and to take the pattern from the time series data. I will use the Battery Center method. So like Barry Center is similar to the center, but Center is for the two-dimensional or the three-dimensional data, but the Battery Center will be the center of the time series data now, I will Store The Battery Center in a library kind of thing. And that is the training part. And now then I will again do the clustering on the Testing period of the monitoring period and now I will try to see now after the Clusters has been done and the patterns are have been generated based on the time series data. I will try to check with the library like whether this patterns are already present inside the library or they are the new patterns now if they are already present inside the library and like because we already know that all the patterns inside the library is supposed to be from the budo if it's because no alarm was raised. So in that way we will try to like there were two ways either inside the Library if there is some pattern and the user have already informed us that this pattern is a bad pattern and if we get the same pattern in the monitoring period then we can directly say that these are bad patterns, but if a new pattern will come up which is not there inside our library and we don't know anything about it then all so we will try to inform the user about the new Pattern from the clustering that came up and like that will be kind of a Softail on to the user and they will check and verify and will fit back to us whether that pattern is a actual bad pattern or not. But because like clustering is a unsupervised method. So the important task here is to detect new patterns, and and we did that quite successful. Yeah.

Interviewer: Leveraging open-source solutions and staying updated with the latest research through platforms like Hugging Face is a solid strategy. When it comes to implementing these cutting-edge techniques in a smartphone environment, what are the key considerations you keep in mind to ensure that the models are not only compressed effectively but also run efficiently on the limited hardware resources of a smartphone?  


Interviewee: Basically, before compression, we try to see the efficiency of the model in a normal environment. Like, in a busy environment or over a cloud. And if you see that the, efficiency of that model is good, then we plan about compressing and we compress it based on the, smartphone capabilities. So, basically, if a model requires, like, 8 GB RAM, to, be executed in a device, then we just try to execute on devices which have minimum of, like, 12 GB RAM. So that the model has some, hardware, available for it to be executed effectively. If the smartphone itself has a 4 GB RAM, and the model can execute only for a 8 GB RAM, then basically we try to still compress and see, like, whether that can be, integrated to that particular device. And, obviously, if the effects are not good, then we just don't try to optimize or compress it for that smart smartphone. We just go for the higher end models.

Interviewee: Drop what is a regularization technique using neural networks to prevent overfitting and improve the generalization of the model in Dropout during training randomly selected neurons are ignored or dropped out with a certain probability typically between 0.2 and 0.5. This means that the contributions to the activation of Downstream neurons are temporarily removed on the forward pass and the weights are not updated during back propagation. And Dropout contributes through the generalization of model reducing overweight encouraging robustness acting as model averaging overall drop over to the powerful legalization technique that helps better to unseen data by reducing over creating encouraging robustness and effectively programming model averaging during inference.
Question: Certainly. Could you explain the concept of 'dropout' in neural networks and how it contributes to the generalization of a model?

And Dropout contributes through the generalization of model reducing overweight encouraging robustness acting as model averaging overall drop over to the powerful legalization technique that helps better to unseen data by reducing over creating encouraging robustness and effectively programming model averaging during inference.

You mentioned extending the Sampled Policy Gradient algorithm for continuous control tasks. Can you walk me through the specific modifications you made to SPG and how these changes improved its performance or stability in your experiments?  

Interviewee: Yes. So reinforcement learning is something that I love and I would like to keep talking about reinforcement learning in this particular interview. Number one SPG is a sampled policy gradient. So essentially how it works is In a really fpg is an actor critic, you know architecture. So at every instance when the actor has to choose a particular action in SPG, what we do is we sample actions by adding noise to The Chosen action. And then we see with the Q value of the chosen action and the sample action. And we compare which has a higher Q value and then we choose that particular action as our actors action and environment. This is the underlying of working of SVG. But the issue with SPG was when we have a continuous action space the you know, the number of actions that you need to choose from is very high. so when we are doing this the issue was SPG did not converge very well. So I explored I explored two things one as I proposed a new quantile truncated distribution reinforcement learning where we have a distributional learning curve that will help us in converging faster and quicker. However, this takes more computational resources.

Interviewer: Given the criticality of accuracy in financial pricing, your approach to model validation is quite insightful. Now, considering the interpretability of AI models in the financial domain is crucial for regulatory compliance and client trust, how did you address the interpretability of your ResNet model? Additionally, could you explain how you quantitatively assessed the model's interpretability and ensured that the output could be explained to non-technical stakeholders?  


Interviewee: Uh, so per off sea regulations, which is the Canadian regulatory Branch the respective validation must match the original Monte Carlo based price or accuracy. So if we were to able to recreate both trades that were seen in the market and synthetic trades that were out of the market domain by a certain bound it would meet Regulatory Compliance as in accordance to Canadian regulatory specifications. In terms of explaining it to shareholders the residual Network or any rectangular based architecture for regression problems are extremely straightforward. They're always rectangular shape. They don't require too many complicated steps to explain to shareholders and because that and because they replicate the price are the original Monte Carlo price or to a reasonable degree of accuracy model validation teams are okay with validating something that they already have a baseline to validate aka the Monte Carlo pricer that they already own.

Interviewer: Fascinating approach to data security and training efficiency. Shifting focus to your AI model development, you mentioned using ResNet for pricing models. Can you discuss how you selected the architecture for the ResNet model? Specifically, what criteria did you consider to determine that ResNet was the most suitable architecture for your financial asset pricing model, and how did you handle model interpretability in the context of financial decision-making?  


Interviewee: So the residual Network or what I refer to as reznet contains skip connections which enable the solution to something called The Vanishing gradient problem. That is why we selected this architecture and because it's a regression problem where the output of the pricer is usually a quantitative value in dollar amount for an option. The accuracy of these numbers are very very relevant. So by employing the residual skip connections we were able to increase our capacity increase our accuracy. In terms of whether or not the architecture was viable. We would actually try to recreate the Monte Carlo based pricer as a result. So we knew exactly what the output should be and therefore we could train to a certain degree of accuracy and generate more data as needed until we achieve that accuracy via the Monte Carlo price.
Question: Fascinating approach to data security and training efficiency. Shifting focus to your AI model development, you mentioned using ResNet for pricing models. Can you discuss how you selected the architecture for the ResNet model? Specifically, what criteria did you consider to determine that ResNet was the most suitable architecture for your financial asset pricing model, and how did you handle model interpretability in the context of financial decision-making?
Response: So the residual Network or what I refer to as reznet contains skip connections which enable the solution to something called The Vanishing gradient problem. That is why we selected this architecture and because it's a regression problem where the output of the pricer is usually a quantitative value in dollar amount for an option. The accuracy of these numbers are very very relevant. So by employing the residual skip connections we were able to increase our capacity increase our accuracy. In terms of whether or not the architecture was viable. We would actually try to recreate the Monte Carlo based pricer as a result. So we knew exactly what the output should be and therefore we could train to a certain degree of accuracy and generate more data as needed until we achieve that accuracy via the Monte Carlo price.

Interviewer: Great! Can you tell me more about your experience developing the digit recognition model using TensorFlow and Keras at NeuroNexus Innovations? What were the key challenges you faced? 


Interviewee: Yeah. While the objective of my technical endeavor was to develop a machine learning model, that can accurately recognize handwritten digits from an image And, like, I used Python programming language for developing the project and various Python libraries such as NumPy, Pandas, MyBotClip, and Skit learn for data preprocessing visualization, and modeling. And for the digit recognition task, I used convolutional neural network, CNN, is a deep learning algorithm that works well with image data Specifically, I use the Keras frame framework to build the CNN model. And there are some challenges like, the biggest challenge in this project was to identifying the best CNN architecture and hyperparameters to achieve high accuracy in digit recognition. Additionally, preprocessing the data to remove noise and ensure uniformity across different images was also challenges. And during the project, I gained a deeper understanding of deep learning algorithm, specifically CNN. And how they can use, to solve image recognition tasks. I learned how to preprocess image data for training and testing and how to tune parameters, hyperparameters, to optimize model performance and how to evaluate model accuracy. And, there are some steps like data processing, model building, model compilation, model training, model evaluation, model saving, and model predictions.

Interviewee: It so there are two approaches to this. One of them is creating a dynamic library and then calling it from python. So the dynamic library is basically a static Library which you compile with a standard C+ compiler like GCC or clang and then you would call it via a subprocess in Python. And the only way you were transfer data between the dynamic library and the python is through the python perimeters which are written in C. Um, another way of alleviating this position where it's much more advanced to something called piind 11 with pipeline. You can basically do one-to-one mappings between Python object like a numpy array down to AC plus of floating Point representation either float 32 or double or so on so forth. So effectively you can either do static Dynamic Library linking or using a pipeline

Interviewer: Certainly! In Python, the "yield" keyword is used in the context of defining a generator function. When you use "yield" in a function instead of "return", it transforms the function into a generator. The key difference is that "return" terminates a function and sends a specified value back to its caller, while "yield" pauses the function, saves its state, and then continues from where it left off the next time it's called. This ability to pause and resume execution is what makes generators memory efficient, as they don't need to store all their values in memory at once. Instead, they generate values on the fly, which can significantly reduce memory usage, especially with large datasets or computations. Given this explanation, how might you now consider using the "yield" keyword in your Python projects, particularly in the context of AI and ML where memory efficiency is a concern?

Interviewer: Certainly. Could you explain the concept of 'dropout' in neural networks and how it contributes to the generalization of a model? 

Interviewee: Dropout is a technique where randomly selected neurons are ignored during training. They are dropped out randomly. This means that their contribution to the activation of Downstream neurons is temporarily removed and on the forward pass and any weight updates are not applied to the neuron on the backward pass.
Question: Certainly. Could you explain the concept of 'dropout' in neural networks and how it contributes to the generalization of a model?
Response: Dropout is a technique where randomly selected neurons are ignored during training. They are dropped out randomly. This means that their contribution to the activation of Downstream neurons is temporarily removed and on the forward pass and any weight updates are not applied to the neuron on the backward pass.
